children.definition: Within the small-cap tier, the subset of CAs (~80%) requiring pro forma leverage test compliance.
children.name: With Leverage Test (80%)

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 82 (d. Permitted Acquisitions)

children.definition: Within the small-cap tier, the subset of CAs (~47%) requiring the acquisition target to have positive EBITDA.
children.name: Positive EBITDA Required (47%)

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Small-market acquisition cap tier ($5-10M fixed / 25% EBITDA), typical of LMM deals. Often paired with leverage test and positive EBITDA requirement.
children.name: $5-10M / 25% (Small)

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition: Mid-market acquisition cap tier ($15-25M fixed / 35% EBITDA), typical of CMM deals. Broader capacity but still size-constrained.
children.name: $15-25M / 35% (Medium)

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition: Large-market acquisition cap tier ($30-50M fixed / 45% EBITDA), typical of UMM deals. May include strategic acquisition tiers with higher leverage allowance. Super-sized acquisition tier for strategic deals exceeding $100M, gated by higher leverage tolerance (e.g., 5.0x). Rare, found in large-cap deals.
children.name: $30-50M / 45% (Large)

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition: Uncapped permitted acquisitions (1.7% of CAs), relying entirely on pro forma compliance conditions rather than dollar limits. Found in borrower-friendly BSL deals.
children.name: Unlimited (1.7%)

red_flags.text: Permitted acquisitions uncapped or cap exceeds 100% of EBITDA — allows transformative acquisitions without effective size constraint

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 81 (c. Investments); Review Template Row 88 (Negative Covenants – Investments); Review Template Row 93 (Negative Covenants – Investments – Ratio Basket)

children.definition: Dollar and/or EBITDA-percentage cap on permitted acquisition size, structured as fixed, grower, or greater-of. The primary sizing control on M&A activity.
children.name: Dollar / EBITDA Cap

red_flags.text: Permitted acquisitions uncapped or cap exceeds 100% of EBITDA — allows transformative acquisitions without effective size constraint

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 76 (e. Capex)

children.definition: Total net leverage ratio test (most common), requiring pro forma total net leverage not to exceed a specified level or closing date ratio.
children.name: Total Net Leverage Test

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 82 (d. Permitted Acquisitions)

children.definition: First lien net leverage ratio as an alternative test, typically more permissive than total net leverage. Allows acquisitions that increase unsecured leverage.
children.name: First Lien Test (Alternative)

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); Review Template Row 25 (Incremental Amount – prepayments); Review Template Row 26 (Incremental Amount – ratio)

children.definition: No-worse-than-closing-date leverage test, permitting acquisitions where pro forma leverage does not exceed closing date levels regardless of absolute ratio.
children.name: No-Worse-Than-Closing Test

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 93 (Negative Covenants – Investments – Ratio Basket)

children.definition: Pro forma leverage ratio test required for permitted acquisitions. Tests are measured giving pro forma effect to the acquisition.
children.name: Leverage Test (65.5%)

red_flags.text: Permitted acquisitions with no leverage test requirement — acquisition can close at any leverage level

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 82 (d. Permitted Acquisitions)

children.definition: Condition requiring no event of default exists or would result from the acquisition.
children.name: No Default / EoD (72.4%)

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 82 (d. Permitted Acquisitions); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Sub-cap limiting the portion of acquisition consideration allocable to non-guarantor subsidiaries. Controls structural leakage from acquisitions of foreign or non-loan-party targets.
children.name: Non-Guarantor Sub-Cap (63.8%)

red_flags.text: No cap on investments in non-guarantor restricted subsidiaries — creates structural leakage below the credit group

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Non-guarantor/foreign subsidiary debt

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: KCT Cat 2 Item 3; Review Template Row 83 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Non-guarantor/foreign subsidiary debt)

children.definition: Requirement that the acquisition target have positive EBITDA (or, in some CAs, positive consolidated net income) for the most recent test period.
children.name: Positive EBITDA Requirement (34.5%)

red_flags.text: No positive EBITDA requirement for acquisition targets — permits acquisitions of cash-burning entities that dilute credit quality

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 8

children.definition: Quality of earnings report requirement for acquisitions exceeding a dollar threshold. Commissioned by borrower, delivered to agent.
children.name: Quality of Earnings Report (10.3%)

red_flags.text: No quality of earnings report required for acquisitions above materiality threshold — inadequate due diligence protection

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA); DLS Preferred Row 82 (d. Permitted Acquisitions)

children.definition: Requirement that the acquisition target operate in a similar or complementary line of business as defined in the credit agreement.
children.name: Similar Business Test (10.3%)

red_flags.text: Similar business test defined broadly to include any business 'reasonably related' or 'complementary' — no meaningful constraint on diversification

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition); DLS Preferred Row 60 (a. Lender Selection)

children.definition: Whether the credit agreement explicitly permits LCA treatment for acquisitions.
children.name: LCA Permitted

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition: Scope of LCA applicability: acquisitions only, all specified transactions, or selective. BSL typically 'all specified transactions'; PC often 'acquisitions only'.
children.name: LCA Scope

red_flags.text: LCA (Limited Condition Acquisition) scope extends to all specified transactions, not just acquisitions — frozen test date for all basket usage

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 78 (Affirmative covenants)

children.definition: Maximum time allowed between LCA measurement date and closing, typically 12-18 months.
children.name: Max Period Between Signing and Closing

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA); DLS Preferred Row 76 (e. Capex)

children.definition: Mechanism allowing measurement of financial tests at signing rather than closing for qualifying acquisitions, providing deal certainty.
children.name: Limited Condition Acquisition (LCA)

red_flags.text: LCA (Limited Condition Acquisition) scope extends to all specified transactions, not just acquisitions — frozen test date for all basket usage

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition)

children.definition: Requirement that acquired entity become a guarantor within specified period (typically 60-90 days) after closing.
children.name: Post-Closing Guarantor Joinder

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 94 (Negative Covenants – Investments – Permitted Acquisitions)

children.definition: Whether the acquisition target must be a domestic entity or may include foreign targets.
children.name: Domestic Entity Requirement

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans)

children.definition: Target must operate in a similar or complementary line of business. Defined by reference to the Line of Business covenant.
children.name: Similar Business Test

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition); DLS Preferred Row 60 (a. Lender Selection)

children.definition: Whether the acquisition is structured as an equity purchase or an asset purchase, affecting collateral and guarantee treatment.

children.definition: Conditions the acquisition target must satisfy: same line of business, domestic vs. foreign, subsidiary vs. third party, guarantor status post-closing.
children.name: Target Requirements

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 82 (d. Permitted Acquisitions); Review Template Row 94 (Negative Covenants – Investments – Permitted Acquisitions)

children.definition: Dollar threshold above which a Quality of Earnings report is required for the acquisition. Typically $25-75M.
children.name: Quality of Earnings Threshold

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA); DLS Preferred Row 82 (d. Permitted Acquisitions)

children.definition: Specific pro forma leverage ratio threshold that must be satisfied for an acquisition to qualify as permitted, calculated after giving effect to the acquisition price, financing, and target EBITDA. The test level is commonly set at the closing-date leverage ratio or 0.25x inside, and may step down over time in deals with scheduled deleveraging expectations.
children.name: Leverage Ratio Test

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 9 (Accordion); DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans)

children.definition: Pro forma compliance with all financial covenants (springing or maintenance) as of most recent test period.
children.name: Financial Covenant Compliance

children.definition: Requirement that material representations and warranties be accurate at time of acquisition.
children.name: Rep & Warranty Bringdown

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition: Condition requiring pro forma compliance with financial ratios after giving effect to a proposed acquisition and any associated financing. Ensures that acquisition activity does not push leverage above negotiated thresholds. The pro forma calculation typically includes the target's trailing EBITDA and gives effect to projected synergies and cost savings to the extent permitted by the EBITDA definition.
children.name: Pro Forma Compliance

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 9 (Accordion); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition)

children.definition: Maximum consideration for any single acquisition. May be uncapped in BSL, typically $25-50M in LMM.
children.name: Single Transaction Cap

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 82 (d. Permitted Acquisitions); Review Template Row 68 (Negative Covenants – Unrestricted Subsidiaries – Envision); Review Template Row 97 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – 75% Cash Consideration Basket)

children.definition: Cumulative cap across all permitted acquisitions during the term.
children.name: Aggregate Cap

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 82 (d. Permitted Acquisitions); Review Template Row 68 (Negative Covenants – Unrestricted Subsidiaries – Envision)

children.definition: Aggregate and per-transaction caps on permitted acquisition size, typically expressed as fixed dollar and/or EBITDA percentage (greater-of).
children.name: Sizing Caps

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 66 (Negative Covenants – carryforward/carryback); Review Template Row 68 (Negative Covenants – Unrestricted Subsidiaries – Envision); Review Template Row 88 (Negative Covenants – Investments)

children.definition: Framework governing allowed acquisitions. Per Learning Material: 'Requirements: The target of the acquisition operates in a similar business. The acquisition target becomes a guarantor and its assets and equity interests are pledged as part of the collateral to the extent required by the guarantee and collateral covenant, often with a cap on acquisitions of entities that do not become guarantors.' Per DLS Preferred row 81: permitted acquisitions typically fall within the intercompany investment framework (Loan Party to Loan Party unlimited) or the general basket. The largest and most complex investment basket by size and conditions.

children.definition: Fixed-dollar or EBITDA-percentage basket for ordinary-course investments not tied to specific purposes. Per DLS Preferred row 81(iv): 'a general fixed-dollar basket.' Per Learning Material: 'Could be used for any investment. This and the other baskets often include a grower based on a percentage of EBITDA or total assets.' Per PC Term Comparison: 'Cap non-Loan Party Investments (in CMM/LMM may be a shared cap with intercompany debt and asset sales).' The catch-all investment capacity, present in nearly all CAs.

children.definition: Investments in restricted subsidiaries that are not guarantors, controlling structural leakage from the credit group to entities outside the guarantee net. Per DLS Preferred row 81(iii): 'an amount to be agreed permitting ordinary course intercompany investments by a Loan Party to other subsidiaries that are not Loan Parties.' Per PC Term Comparison: 'Cap non-Loan Party Investments (in CMM/LMM may be a shared cap with intercompany debt and asset sales).' This is the critical Tier 2 leakage boundary per the Intro Guide: assets move from Loan Parties (where lenders have both collateral interest and senior debt claim) to non-guarantor restricted subs (where lenders retain only indirect equity interest).

Per KCT Cat 4 Item 2, unlimited investments in unrestricted subsidiaries without reference to baskets or ratios is a risk escalation item. Per Learning Material, management equity repurchases are 'typically a dollar amount per year, which increases following an IPO.' Management loans mirror this structure but are investments rather than restricted payments. Per PC Term Comparison: management buyback carrybacks should be avoided; limited carryforwards with EoD stopper. Typically small fixed caps relative to deal size.

golden_record_refs.representative_text: (xi)any transaction which is an Investment permitted by Section 9.6 (including, without limitation, any Permitted Acquisition), Section 9.7 (including, without limitation, Investments arising out of t

children.name: Management Loans / Employee Advances

red_flags.text: Management loan / officer advance basket with no individual cap and ability to roll or forgive loans — disguised distributions

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: Learning Material Section (7)(3): 'typically a dollar amount per year, increases following IPO.' PC Term Comparison: 'Avoid carry backs, limit carryforwards to one year, include EoD stopper.'
pc_ref: : 'Avoid carry backs, limit carryforwards to one year, include EoD stopper.'

children.definition: Dollar or EBITDA-percentage cap on similar business investments. Some CAs have no explicit cap.
children.name: Cap Amount

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 82 (d. Permitted Acquisitions); Review Template Row 68 (Negative Covenants – Unrestricted Subsidiaries – Envision)

children.definition: How 'similar business' is defined: by reference to closing date activities, reasonable extensions, SIC/NAICS codes, or broadly as 'complementary'. Breadth of definition is a key borrower-friendliness marker.
children.name: Similar Business Definition

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 60 (a. Lender Selection); DLS Preferred Row 82 (d. Permitted Acquisitions)

children.definition: Whether similar business investments require pro forma leverage test compliance.
children.name: Leverage Gating

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 41 (Maximum leverage)

children.definition: Investments in businesses similar to or complementary to the borrower's permitted line of business. Per Learning Material: 'substantively acts as another general investments basket.' The breadth of the 'similar business' or 'Permitted Business' definition is a key negotiation point -- broadly defined permits diversification beyond core operations; narrowly defined keeps assets within the borrower's proven competency. Per PC Term Comparison: clients should 'highlight for client the other baskets (eg, similar business, jv etc if applicable).'

children.name: Similar Business Investments

red_flags.text: Similar business test defined broadly to include any business 'reasonably related' or 'complementary' — no meaningful constraint on diversification

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: Learning Material Section (6): 'substantively acts as another general investments basket.' PC Term Comparison: highlight similar business basket size for client.
pc_ref: : highlight similar business basket size for client.

children.definition: Investments made in the ordinary course of business, including trade credit, customer deposits, and supplier prepayments. ~31.0% frequency as explicit basket.
children.name: Ordinary Course (31.0%)
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 60 (a. Lender Selection); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA)

children.definition: Intercompany investments and promissory notes between restricted group entities. ~23.8% frequency as a separate basket within other investments.
children.name: Intercompany / Promissory Notes (23.8%)
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 81 (c. Investments)

children.definition: Investment basket permitting deployment of funds into cash equivalents as defined in the credit agreement (typically short-term, highly liquid investments such as treasury securities, money market funds, and commercial paper rated at least A-1/P-1). This blanket permission ensures that routine treasury management activity does not consume limited investment basket capacity.
children.name: Cash and Cash Equivalents
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Investments existing on the closing date as identified on a schedule to the credit agreement.
children.name: Closing Date Investments
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 81 (c. Investments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Investments constituting hedging agreements and swap obligations entered into for bona fide hedging purposes.
children.name: Swap / Hedging Investments
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 81 (c. Investments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Investment basket permitting extensions of credit to customers, vendors, and counterparties in the ordinary course of business. Covers standard commercial payment terms (net 30, net 60) and volume rebate arrangements that create receivable positions, representing the financing component inherent in normal business operations.
children.name: trade credit

children.definition: Qualifying condition limiting the trade credit investment basket to extensions of credit arising from the borrower's customary commercial activities, as distinguished from financial investments or speculative lending. The 'ordinary course' limitation requires consistency with past practice in terms of credit terms, customer types, and concentration levels.
children.name: ordinary course of business
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 60 (a. Lender Selection); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Investment basket permitting the borrower to maintain accounts receivable arising from sales of goods and services in the ordinary course. Recognizes that trade receivables represent an inherent investment in working capital rather than a discretionary deployment of funds, and ensures that routine revenue-generating activity does not trigger investment covenant limitations.
children.name: accounts receivable
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA)

children.definition: Trade credit extended to customers or received from suppliers in the ordinary course of business.
children.name: Trade Credit Ordinary Course
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 60 (a. Lender Selection); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA)

children.definition: Investments funded with proceeds of equity issuances (excluded contributions), providing additional capacity outside basket limits.
children.name: Equity-Funded Investments
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 53 (p. Amendments to Acquisition Agreement); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Investment basket permitting investments received in connection with the bankruptcy or insolvency proceedings of counterparties, including equity or debt securities received in satisfaction of pre-petition claims, plan distributions, and court-ordered settlements. Prevents the borrower from being forced to reject recovery consideration due to investment covenant constraints.
children.name: bankruptcy

children.definition: Investment basket permitting investments received as part of a court-approved reorganization plan of a debtor counterparty, including new equity, reorganized debt, or other securities distributed to creditors. Distinguished from bankruptcy receipts in that these represent negotiated restructuring consideration rather than liquidation distributions.
children.name: reorganization

children.definition: Investment basket permitting investments received in settlement or compromise of delinquent accounts, disputed claims, or litigation, including equity stakes, promissory notes, or other non-cash consideration accepted in lieu of full cash payment. Ensures that practical resolution of distressed counterparty situations is not blocked by the investment covenant.
children.name: settlement of delinquent

children.definition: Investments received in settlement of bankruptcy claims or as part of workout/restructuring proceedings.
children.name: Bankruptcy Settlement Proceeds
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 78 (Affirmative covenants)

children.definition: Investment basket permitting the sale or pledge of receivables to a securitization vehicle as part of a permitted receivables financing facility. Covers the borrower's retained interests, residual certificates, and servicing obligations that constitute 'investments' in the securitization entity under the covenant framework.
children.name: Permitted Receivables Financing
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans)

children.definition: Investment basket permitting equity investments in a special purpose subsidiary formed to hold and manage receivables for a securitization program. The subsidiary must be bankruptcy-remote with independent directors and limited-purpose organizational documents, and the investment typically represents the borrower's residual equity interest in the receivables pool.
children.name: Receivables Subsidiary
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 67 (Security); Review Template Row 68 (Negative Covenants – Unrestricted Subsidiaries – Envision); Review Template Row 95 (Negative Covenants – Investments – Other)

children.definition: Investment basket permitting the structural components of a securitization transaction that constitute investments under the covenant framework, including retained subordinated tranches, credit enhancement deposits, reserve accounts, and servicing advance obligations. These retained interests align the borrower's economic incentives with the securitization investors.
children.name: Securitization
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 80 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Securitization Facilities); Review Template Row 101 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – Securitizations)

children.definition: Investments in connection with qualified receivables facilities and securitization programs.
children.name: Receivables Securitization
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 80 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Securitization Facilities)

children.definition: Sub-component capturing alternative phrasing of non-cash consideration (without hyphen) as an investment basket keyword variant, functionally equivalent to non_cash_consideration but appearing as a distinct term cluster in corpus analysis.
children.name: noncash consideration
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 82 (d. Permitted Acquisitions)

children.definition: Investment basket permitting the borrower to receive and hold non-cash consideration (equity interests, promissory notes, or other instruments) from asset dispositions rather than requiring immediate liquidation into cash. Prevents the investment covenant from forcing the borrower to accept below-market cash offers when non-cash consideration maximizes total recovery value.
children.name: non-cash consideration
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Investment basket covering the deemed investment that occurs when the borrower receives non-cash proceeds from an asset sale that was itself permitted under the dispositions covenant. This basket bridges the two covenants by ensuring that a properly permitted asset sale does not fail solely because the resulting non-cash consideration constitutes an investment.
children.name: Dispositions permitted
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Investments constituting non-cash consideration received in connection with permitted dispositions.
children.name: Non-Cash Disposition Proceeds
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 67 (Security)

children.definition: A carveout permitting investments that also qualify as permitted under other negative covenants (e.g., permitted indebtedness, permitted liens).
children.name: Cross-Reference Basket
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 146 (Cross-default)

children.definition: Investments consisting of deposits held in ordinary course deposit accounts, typically uncapped as a permitted investment.
children.name: Deposit Account Investments
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 67 (Security); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 81 (c. Investments)

children.definition: Investments in customers or suppliers in the ordinary course of business, including prepaid inventory and customer financing.
children.name: Customer / Supplier Investments
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 81 (c. Investments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Investments constituting pledges or deposits in connection with workers compensation, health, disability, or other insurance obligations.
children.name: Insurance / Surety Investments
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 78 (Affirmative covenants); DLS Preferred Row 81 (c. Investments)

children.definition: Investments in the form of deferred purchase price, earnout payments, or indemnification obligations arising from permitted acquisitions.
children.name: Earnout / Purchase Price Adjustment Payments
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 53 (p. Amendments to Acquisition Agreement)

children.definition: Investment basket permitting the acquisition, licensing, or development of intellectual property rights (patents, trademarks, copyrights, trade secrets, and technology) in the ordinary course of business. Recognizes that IP transactions essential to operations constitute investments under the covenant but should not consume limited general basket capacity reserved for strategic investments.
children.name: Intellectual Property
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 52 (o. Collateral); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 78 (Affirmative covenants)

children.definition: Investment basket for endorsements of negotiable instruments for deposit or collection in the ordinary course of business. A routine banking carveout recognizing that check processing and similar payment collection activities are not discretionary investments.
children.name: Endorsements Collection

children.definition: Investment basket for gaming-industry-specific investments including gaming licenses, regulatory deposits, patron credit facilities, and casino cage operations required by gaming regulatory authorities. Industry-specific carveout for regulated gaming entities.
children.name: Gaming Specific
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 78 (Affirmative covenants); Review Template Row 21 ([DDTL – availability period])

children.definition: Investment basket for investments in convertible debt instruments, preferred stock with conversion features, or other securities with embedded equity conversion rights. Captures the investment component of instruments that may convert to equity.
children.name: Convertible Instruments

children.definition: Investment basket permitting the acquisition of inventory, supplies, materials, and equipment in the ordinary course of business. Ensures that routine procurement activity necessary for operations is not constrained by the investment covenant, which is designed to govern strategic capital deployment rather than working capital purchases.
children.name: Inventory Supplies Purchases
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Miscellaneous investment permissions including ordinary course, intercompany, cash equivalents, closing date investments, hedging, trade credit, equity-funded, receivables securitization, and cross-reference baskets. Per DLS Preferred row 81: preferred position covers intercompany tiers and general basket; alternatives add unlimited ratio basket, high-yield-style shared baskets, and non-guarantor unlimited investments. Per Learning Material, the bond-style format subsumes investments within the RP covenant with a separate 'Permitted Investments' carve-out definition.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Other Investment Baskets

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Other Investment Baskets: (i) unlimited investments in non-guarantor restricted subsidiaries (ii) unlimited investments subject to compliance with a total leverage ratio and no default or event of default (iii) "high yield style" investments, restricted payments and restricted debt prepayments share baskets except for certain baskets only for the benefit of investments
key_negotiation_points: Leverage ratio type for ratio basket
Leverage ratio level for ratio basket
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market standard for investments reflects a negotiated middle ground, with specific terms varying by deal size, leverage profile, and competitive dynamics.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: (i) permitting unlimited ordinary course intercompany investments among Loan Parties (ii) unlimited ordinary course intercompany investments among subsidiaries that are not Loan Parties, (iii) an amount to be agreed permitting ordinary course intercompany investments by a Loan Party to other subsidiaries that are not Loan Parties (iv) a general fixed-dollar basket

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 81: preferred and alternative baskets. Learning Material: bond-style format subsumes investments within RP covenant.

children.definition: Reclassification of restricted payment basket capacity as investment capacity, allowing unused RP headroom to fund investments. Typically bidirectional with investment-to-RP redesignation.
children.name: From Restricted Payments (57.7%)

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 84 (Restricted Payments)

children.definition: Reclassification of restricted debt payment basket capacity as investment capacity, allowing unused RDP headroom to fund investments. Less common than RP-to-investment redesignation.
children.name: From Restricted Debt Payments (26.9%)

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 111 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments)

children.definition: Reclassification of asset sale reinvestment capacity as investment capacity.
children.name: From Asset Sales (15.4%)

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 83 (e. Dispositions); Review Template Row 43 (Asset Sale Sweep – Reinvestment)

children.definition: Bond-style integration allowing free movement of capacity between investments, RP, and RDP baskets. Most borrower-flexible approach.
children.name: Bond-Style Integration (11.5%)

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 2

children.definition: Whether unused indebtedness basket capacity can be reclassified as investment capacity.
children.name: From Indebtedness Baskets

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 2

children.definition: Whether reclassification must occur at the time of the investment or may be done retroactively.
children.name: Timing Restrictions

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 64 (Negative Covenants – General)

children.definition: Mechanism permitting reclassification of investments between covenants. Per Learning Material: credit agreements 'often include baskets that allow the borrower to reallocate: Unused capacity under certain RP baskets to be used to make Investments.' Per DLS Preferred row 81 alt(iii): 'high yield style investments, restricted payments and restricted debt prepayments share baskets except for certain baskets only for the benefit of investments.' Per PC Term Comparison: reallocation 'typically limited from RPs to RDPs/Investments and RDPs to Investments but not the other way.'
children.name: Investment Redesignation / Reclassification

red_flags.text: Investment baskets reclassifiable to debt capacity — general or AA investment basket feeds incremental equivalent debt

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: Learning Material: reallocation of RP baskets to investments. DLS Preferred row 81 alt(iii): 'high yield style shared baskets.' PC Term Comparison: reallocation one-directional.

children.definition: Intercompany investments between loan parties (borrower and guarantors). Typically unlimited as they stay within the credit group.
children.name: Loan Party to Loan Party

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 67 (Security); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 81 (c. Investments)

children.definition: Whether LP-to-NLP intercompany loans must be subordinated to the credit agreement obligations.
children.name: Subordination Required

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); Review Template Row 88 (Negative Covenants – Investments)

children.definition: Requirement for a signed intercompany note pledged as collateral to the secured parties.
children.name: Intercompany Note Required

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 81 (c. Investments)

children.definition: Whether LP-to-NLP loans are treated as investments consuming basket capacity rather than pure intercompany transactions.
children.name: Deemed Investment Treatment

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 76 (e. Capex); Review Template Row 68 (Negative Covenants – Unrestricted Subsidiaries – Envision); Review Template Row 88 (Negative Covenants – Investments)

children.definition: Intercompany investments from loan parties to non-loan parties. Consumes non-guarantor investment capacity and typically requires subordination via intercompany note.
children.name: Loan Party to Non-Loan Party

red_flags.text: Intercompany investments from loan parties to non-loan-party subsidiaries without subordination or security requirements

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition); DLS Preferred Row 67 (Security)

children.definition: Intercompany investments from non-loan parties to loan parties. Typically unlimited and welcomed as they increase credit group assets.
children.name: Non-Loan Party to Loan Party

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition); DLS Preferred Row 67 (Security)

children.definition: Intercompany investments between non-loan parties. Typically unlimited as they remain outside the credit group.
children.name: Non-Loan Party to Non-Loan Party

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition); DLS Preferred Row 67 (Security)

children.definition: Permitted intercompany investments among entities within the corporate group. DLS Preferred establishes three tiers: (i) unlimited among Loan Parties, (ii) unlimited among non-Loan Party subsidiaries, and (iii) capped investments from Loan Parties to non-Loan Party subsidiaries (the critical leakage vector). PC Term Comparison: 'Cap non-Loan Party Investments (in CMM/LMM may be a shared cap with intercompany debt and asset sales).'
children.name: Intercompany Investments

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Other Investment Baskets: (i) unlimited investments in non-guarantor restricted subsidiaries (ii) unlimited investments subject to compliance with a total leverage ratio and no default or event of default (iii) "high yield style" investments, restricted payments and restricted debt prepayments share baskets except for certain baskets only for the benefit of investments
key_negotiation_points: Leverage ratio type for ratio basket
Leverage ratio level for ratio basket
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market standard for investments reflects a negotiated middle ground, with specific terms varying by deal size, leverage profile, and competitive dynamics.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: (i) permitting unlimited ordinary course intercompany investments among Loan Parties (ii) unlimited ordinary course intercompany investments among subsidiaries that are not Loan Parties, (iii) an amount to be agreed permitting ordinary course intercompany investments by a Loan Party to other subsidiaries that are not Loan Parties (iv) a general fixed-dollar basket

red_flags.text: Intercompany investments from loan parties to non-loan-party subsidiaries without subordination or security requirements

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 81(i)-(iii). PC Term Comparison: 'Cap non-Loan Party Investments (in CMM/LMM may be a shared cap with intercompany debt and asset sales).'

children.definition: Interest rate swaps and caps entered to manage floating rate exposure on credit facility debt.
children.name: Interest Rate Hedging
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA); DLS Preferred Row 78 (Affirmative covenants)

children.definition: Foreign currency forward contracts and swaps to manage FX exposure from foreign operations.
children.name: Currency Hedging
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 18 (Revolver currencies)

children.definition: Commodity futures and forward contracts to manage price exposure on key inputs or outputs.
children.name: Commodity Hedging

children.definition: Requirement that hedging be for bona fide hedging purposes only and not for speculation.
children.name: Speculative Purpose Prohibition

children.definition: Investments consisting of hedging agreements, interest rate swaps, currency swaps, and commodity hedging entered into in the ordinary course and not for speculative purposes. Per DLS Preferred framework: hedging investments are a structural carve-out typically unlimited but limited to bona fide hedging activities. Per Learning Material: investments in the ordinary course of business are among the customary exceptions not counted against capacity baskets.
children.name: Hedging / Swap Investments
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 81 (c. Investments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Investments specifically listed on a closing date schedule, typically with dollar amounts and entity names.
children.name: Schedule-Identified Investments

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 81 (c. Investments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Whether closing date investments may be extended, renewed, or replaced (and if so, whether the amount may increase).
children.name: Extensions and Renewals

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition: Whether additional investments in entities that were investees on the closing date are permitted outside the closing date basket.
children.name: Additional Investments in Existing

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 62 (Right to Appoint Additional Agents)

children.definition: Investments existing on the closing date, identified on a schedule, and deemed permitted. Per Learning Material: this is a structural carve-out -- closing date investments are 'grandfathered' regardless of covenant limitations. Per DLS Preferred framework: existing investments are permitted at closing date levels. Additional investments in existing investees may be limited or may require basket capacity.
children.name: Existing / Closing Date Investments

red_flags.text: Existing / closing date investments basket permits growth, reinvestment, and roll-over of pre-closing positions without cap

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 81 (c. Investments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Whether restricted payment basket capacity may be used for investments.
children.name: RP Capacity Used as Investments

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 81 (c. Investments)

children.definition: Whether investment basket capacity may be used for restricted payments.
children.name: Investment Capacity Used as RP

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Whether the same action can be characterized as either an RP or an investment at the borrower's election, allowing covenant arbitrage.
children.name: RP / Investment Fungibility

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 68 (Negative Covenants – Unrestricted Subsidiaries – Envision); Review Template Row 88 (Negative Covenants – Investments); Review Template Row 89 (Negative Covenants – Investments – Investments in non-Loan Parties)

children.definition: How intercompany indebtedness interacts with investment covenant: LP-to-NLP debt often consumes investment capacity.
children.name: Indebtedness Coordination

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (Indebtedness)

children.definition: Whether reinvestment rights from asset sale proceeds can be deployed as investments.
children.name: Disposition Reinvestment Interaction

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); Review Template Row 43 (Asset Sale Sweep – Reinvestment); Review Template Row 88 (Negative Covenants – Investments)

children.definition: Provisions preventing the same capacity from being counted under multiple covenants simultaneously.
children.name: Anti-Double-Dip Provisions

heading_patterns: Investments, Loans, Advances, Guarantees and Acquisitions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 67 (Security); DLS Preferred Row 78 (Affirmative covenants)

children.definition: Rules governing how investment capacity interacts with other negative covenants. Per Learning Material: 'Some top-tier sponsor form credit agreements use bond-style format; however some sponsors prefer to keep the 3 separate covenants because the separate covenants provide opportunity for multiple baskets.' Per DLS Preferred row 81 alt(iii): 'high yield style investments, restricted payments and restricted debt prepayments share baskets except for certain baskets only for the benefit of investments.' Cross-covenant links include: indebtedness coordination (intercompany debt deemed investments), RP/investment fungibility, disposition reinvestment, and the Available Amount shared pool.

children.name: Cross-Covenant Coordination

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Other Investment Baskets: (i) unlimited investments in non-guarantor restricted subsidiaries (ii) unlimited investments subject to compliance with a total leverage ratio and no default or event of default (iii) "high yield style" investments, restricted payments and restricted debt prepayments share baskets except for certain baskets only for the benefit of investments

definition: The negative covenant controlling the deployment of credit group cash and assets into non-collateral entities, joint ventures, unrestricted subsidiaries, and financial instruments. Per DLS Preferred, the bank position permits: (i) unlimited ordinary course intercompany investments among Loan Parties, (ii) unlimited among non-Loan Party subsidiaries, (iii) capped investments by Loan Parties to non-Loan Party subsidiaries, and (iv) a general fixed-dollar basket. Investments and RDPs are similar to equity RPs in that value is leaving the credit group, but the borrower receives something of value in return, so creditors prefer investments to equity distributions. Leakage through investments flows 'down' from loan parties to entities not directly pledged to lenders.

name: Investments

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Other Investment Baskets: (i) unlimited investments in non-guarantor restricted subsidiaries (ii) unlimited investments subject to compliance with a total leverage ratio and no default or event of default (iii) "high yield style" investments, restricted payments and restricted debt prepayments share baskets except for certain baskets only for the benefit of investments
